title: Is it ethical to make money off your own lecture notes?
body: Recently, a non-tenured professor was fired by a small regional university. While several reasons were given, I find the main reasons questionable and want to check them against generally accepted norms:

items: The professor published his own lecture notes online, and at the bottom of each page, there was a "Buy me a coffee" link that allowed users to donate money directly to him. This link only appeared on the notes he made available through his professional website hosted on GitHub. He also had a version uploaded to the university's e-learning system, where students could download the PDF version without seeing the donation link.
The professor published YouTube videos in which he read his own lectures with some animations and illustrations. He monetized these videos and received profit.

The professor published several technical reports that summarized long and technical papers, as well as famous but complicated experiments, in a form that was understandable for students. These were also published on his professional site with the "Buy me a coffee" link.

body:
Over the last few years, the professor made a small amount of money through these three sources. The university ruled that this broke the ethical code, even though there were no explicit clauses in the faculty handbook addressing these actions.
My question is: Regardless of the university's perspective, do any of these actions break the generally accepted ethical code?
